title: Metabolic Encephalopathy
scope: ** Evaluation and management of encephalopathy due to metabolic derangements in adults. Covers four major etiologies: (1) Hepatic encephalopathy, (2) Uremic encephalopathy, (3) Electrolyte-related encephalopathy (hyponatremia, hypercalcemia, hypernatremia), and (4) Endocrine/glucose-related encephalopathy (hypoglycemia, myxedema coma). Applies to ED, hospital, outpatient, and ICU settings. Excludes Wernicke encephalopathy (separate plan — nutritional/thiamine deficiency), hypertensive encephalopathy (separate plan — vascular mechanism), and drug-induced neurotoxicity (separate plan).

Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal WBC; platelets >50,000; no left shift

Hepatic encephalopathy; collect on ice, analyze within 30 min; elevated >35 micromol/L suggestive of HE
Essential/Core Labs.target: <35 micromol/L (normal); note: correlates poorly with severity

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hypoglycemic encephalopathy; rapid bedside check followed by lab confirmation
Hyponatremic or hypernatremic encephalopathy; note rate of change matters more than absolute value
Essential/Core Labs.target: 136-145 mEq/L; <120 mEq/L = severe hyponatremia; >160 mEq/L = severe hypernatremia

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Uremic encephalopathy; BUN >60-100 mg/dL correlates with neurologic symptoms
Osmolar gap; osmotic demyelination risk assessment; hyperosmolar states
Tissue perfusion assessment; metabolic acidosis; sepsis screening
Acid-base status; respiratory compensation; identify metabolic acidosis/alkalosis
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal pH 7.35-7.45; identify specific acid-base disorder

Essential/Core Labs.target: Ionized Ca 4.6-5.3 mg/dL; total Ca 8.5-10.5 mg/dL

Essential/First-line.target: Exclude structural cause (hemorrhage, mass, hydrocephalus, herniation); CT has low sensitivity for metabolic encephalopathy
Essential/First-line.contraindications: Pregnancy (benefit outweighs risk if clinically indicated)

Essential/First-line.target: **Hepatic:** bilateral globus pallidus T1 hyperintensity (manganese deposition); **Uremic:** cortical/subcortical T2/FLAIR edema; **Hyponatremic:** diffuse cerebral edema; **ODS:** central pontine and/or extrapontine T2/FLAIR hyperintensity; **Hypoglycemic:** bilateral hippocampal, basal ganglia DWI restriction

Essential/First-line.timing: STAT if seizure suspected; URGENT otherwise
Essential/First-line.target: **Hepatic:** triphasic waves (bilateral, frontally predominant); **Uremic:** triphasic waves, diffuse slowing; **All metabolic:** diffuse theta/delta slowing; exclude NCSE

Electrolyte Encephalopathy -- Specific T.indication: Acute (<48h) or symptomatic hyponatremia with neurologic symptoms (seizures, altered consciousness, cerebral edema)

dosing.instructions: 100-150 mL 3% NaCl IV over 20 min; may repeat x2 if persistent severe symptoms (seizures); MAXIMUM correction 8 mEq/L in first 24 hours

Electrolyte Encephalopathy -- Specific T.contraindications: Hypervolemic hyponatremia with volume overload (relative — benefit outweighs risk if symptomatic)
Electrolyte Encephalopathy -- Specific T.monitoring: Serum Na q2h during active correction; neurologic exam; urine output; watch for overcorrection

Electrolyte Encephalopathy -- Specific T.indication: Chronic hyponatremia (>48h or unknown duration) — correct slowly to avoid ODS

doseOptions.orderSentence: Chronic hyponatremia management (>48h) Correct at <=0.5 mEq/L per hour IV/PO

dosing.instructions: Fluid restriction (1-1.5 L/day) first-line; salt tablets 1-3 g PO TID if needed; isotonic saline if hypovolemic; MAXIMUM 8 mEq/L correction in 24h
dosing.orderSentence: Chronic hyponatremia management (>48h) Correct at <=0.5 mEq/L per hour IV/PO

dosing.instructions: 15 mg PO daily; initiate in hospital only; titrate to 30 mg then 60 mg at >=24h intervals if Na not rising; discontinue fluid restriction when starting; max 30 days per FDA label

dosing.instructions: 2 mcg IV if sodium correction exceeds 8 mEq/L in 24h; re-lower sodium to safe correction rate; may give D5W 3-6 mL/kg/h concurrently

Endocrine Encephalopathy -- Specific Tre.indication: First-line thyroid hormone replacement for myxedema coma; IV route mandatory (PO absorption unreliable in myxedema)

dosing.instructions: 200-400 mcg IV loading dose, then 50-100 mcg IV daily until able to take PO; lower loading dose (200 mcg) in elderly or coronary artery disease; transition to PO when clinically improved

Endocrine Encephalopathy -- Specific Tre.contraindications: Uncorrected adrenal insufficiency (give hydrocortisone FIRST); acute MI; severe tachyarrhythmia
Endocrine Encephalopathy -- Specific Tre.monitoring: Heart rate; ECG; TSH and free T4 q24-48h; clinical response; watch for arrhythmia and myocardial ischemia

Endocrine Encephalopathy -- Specific Tre.indication: Empiric stress-dose steroids until adrenal insufficiency excluded; coexistent adrenal insufficiency common in myxedema; give BEFORE levothyroxine

dosing.instructions: 100 mg IV q8h; give BEFORE or concurrent with levothyroxine loading; continue until ACTH stimulation test excludes adrenal insufficiency; taper when stable

Endocrine Encephalopathy -- Specific Tre.contraindications: Active untreated infection (relative — benefit outweighs risk); GI hemorrhage (relative)
Endocrine Encephalopathy -- Specific Tre.monitoring: Blood glucose q6h; electrolytes; cortisol levels; signs of infection

Endocrine Encephalopathy -- Specific Tre.indication: Hypothermia management in myxedema coma; avoid active rewarming (causes vasodilation and cardiovascular collapse)

dosing.instructions: Warm blankets, warm IV fluids, warm humidified oxygen; avoid active external rewarming (heating blankets, warm bath) as it causes peripheral vasodilation and cardiovascular collapse

Endocrine Encephalopathy -- Specific Tre.monitoring: Core temperature q1-2h; hemodynamics; expect slow rise over 24-48h

Endocrine Encephalopathy -- Specific Tre.indication: Respiratory failure from hypoventilation; CO2 narcosis; inability to protect airway

Endocrine Encephalopathy -- Specific Tre.monitoring: Ventilator settings; ABG q4-6h; ETCO2; weaning readiness

Nephrology for uremic encephalopathy, dialysis initiation, renal replacement therapy planning
Endocrinology for myxedema coma, adrenal crisis, complex endocrine derangements
Neurology for EEG interpretation, seizure management, differential diagnosis of encephalopathy, NCSE exclusion
Critical Care / ICU for Grade 3-4 hepatic encephalopathy, myxedema coma, severe electrolyte emergencies requiring ICU-level monitoring
Pharmacy for medication reconciliation, renal dosing adjustments, drug interaction review, lactulose/rifaximin optimization

Social work for discharge planning, medication access, substance abuse resources (if alcohol-related cirrhosis), dialysis transition support
Palliative care for refractory hepatic encephalopathy with advanced cirrhosis not transplant-eligible; goals of care discussion

differential.features: Classic triad: confusion, ophthalmoplegia, ataxia; thiamine deficiency; often coexists with hepatic encephalopathy in alcoholics
differential.tests: Thiamine level; MRI (medial thalamic, mammillary body, periaqueductal changes); response to IV thiamine

differential.features: Temporal relationship with medication initiation or dose change; medication history critical; serotonin syndrome, NMS, lithium toxicity
differential.tests: Drug levels; urine drug screen; medication reconciliation; specific drug levels (lithium, valproate, etc.)

differential.features: Fever; hemodynamic instability; positive cultures; procalcitonin elevation; altered mental status with infection
differential.tests: Blood cultures; procalcitonin; lactate; CRP; imaging for infection source

differential.features: Fever; meningismus; headache; focal neurologic signs; CSF pleocytosis
differential.tests: Lumbar puncture (elevated WBC, low glucose, elevated protein); CSF cultures; HSV PCR; MRI

differential.features: Subacute onset; psychiatric symptoms; seizures; movement disorders; CSF antibodies
differential.tests: Autoimmune encephalitis panel (serum + CSF); MRI (temporal lobe FLAIR changes); EEG

differential.features: Fluctuating altered consciousness; subtle motor signs (eye deviation, nystagmus, automatisms); may coexist with metabolic encephalopathy
differential.tests: Continuous EEG (definitive); trial of benzodiazepine with clinical and electrographic improvement

differential.features: Severe hypertension; seizures; visual changes; posterior predominant vasogenic edema on MRI
differential.tests: MRI (posterior white matter vasogenic edema); blood pressure assessment

differential.features: Hepatorenal syndrome patients may have combined metabolic causes
differential.tests: CMP; ammonia; BUN/Cr; address both liver and renal failure

differential.features: History of cardiac arrest, respiratory failure, severe hypotension; DWI restriction on MRI
differential.tests: Clinical history; ABG; MRI brain (cortical ribbon, basal ganglia DWI restriction); EEG

differential.features: Fluctuating attention; inattention as cardinal feature; often multifactorial in hospitalized elderly patients
differential.tests: CAM assessment; comprehensive metabolic workup; medication review; infection screen; environmental assessment

differential.features: Focal neurologic deficits; asymmetric findings; acute onset (stroke) or progressive (tumor); unilateral imaging findings
differential.tests: CT head (hemorrhage, mass); MRI brain (stroke, tumor); CT angiography (large vessel occlusion)

disposition.criteria: Grade 3-4 hepatic encephalopathy (somnolence, coma); acute symptomatic hyponatremia with seizures or obtundation; myxedema coma; need for continuous EEG monitoring; hemodynamic instability requiring vasopressors; need for CRRT; GCS <=8 requiring intubation; active hypertonic saline infusion requiring q1-2h sodium monitoring

Grade 2 hepatic encephalopathy improving on lactulose; sodium correction requiring q4-6h monitoring; uremic encephalopathy initiating intermittent hemodialysis with improving mental status; post-ICU stabilization with ongoing IV medication needs

Grade 1-2 hepatic encephalopathy on stable lactulose regimen; mild-moderate chronic hyponatremia under fluid restriction; uremic encephalopathy with established dialysis schedule and improving cognition; stable electrolyte abnormalities being corrected

Mental status returned to baseline; underlying metabolic derangement corrected or stable on outpatient regimen; reliable outpatient follow-up arranged; patient/family education completed; medications reconciled and available; for HE: lactulose and rifaximin prescribed, bowel regimen established; for uremia: dialysis schedule confirmed; for hyponatremia: sodium stable >=125 mEq/L and improving, fluid restriction understood

Need for liver transplant evaluation at transplant center; need for emergent dialysis at facility without nephrology; refractory encephalopathy not responding to standard treatment; need for specialized neurological evaluation not available at current facility

Hepatology within 1-2 weeks (hepatic encephalopathy); Nephrology within 1 week (uremic encephalopathy); Endocrinology within 1-2 weeks (myxedema); Neurology within 2-4 weeks (EEG follow-up, seizure management); PCP within 1 week for all; repeat labs (sodium, BUN/Cr, ammonia, LFTs) within 3-7 days per etiology
